articles.headline: Court Tells Reporter to Testify in Case of Leaked C.I.A. Data
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court ruled that James Risen, an author and a reporter for The New York Times, must testify against a former government official charged with giving him classified information.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court ruled that James Risen, an author and a reporter for The New York Times, must testify against a former government official charged with giving him classified information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major ruling on press freedoms, a divided federal appeals court on Friday ruled that James Risen, an author and a reporter for The New York Times, must testify in the criminal trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency official charged with providing him with classified information.

articles.headline: Richer Farmers, Bigger Subsidies
articles.snippet: Lost in the recent debate is the fact that the new farm bill includes more generous subsidies for wealthy farmers even as lawmakers complain about government waste.
articles.abstract: Lost in the recent debate is the fact that the new farm bill includes more generous subsidies for wealthy farmers even as lawmakers complain about government waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a more widely reviled piece of legislation than the nearly $1 trillion farm bill. Its widely ridiculed handouts to wealthy farmers and perverse incentives have long united liberals concerned about the environment, conservatives upset about the deficit and market-distorting subsidies, and just about everyone concerned about basic fairness.

articles.headline: President Offers a Personal Take on Race in U.S.
articles.snippet: In his most extensive remarks on race since 2008, President Obama spoke in personal terms about the experience of being a black man in the United States.
articles.abstract: In his most extensive remarks on race since 2008, President Obama spoke in personal terms about the experience of being a black man in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After days of angry protests and mounting public pressure, President Obama summoned five of his closest advisers to the Oval Office on Thursday evening. It was time, he told them, for him to speak to the nation about the Trayvon Martin verdict, and he had a pretty good idea what he wanted to say.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: S.E.C. Charges Are the Latest Test for SAC’s Cohen
articles.snippet: The case contends that Steven A. Cohen ignored “red flags” that should have led him to investigate suspicious trading activity at SAC Capital Advisors and take steps to prevent illegal conduct.
articles.abstract: The case contends that Steven A. Cohen ignored “red flags” that should have led him to investigate suspicious trading activity at SAC Capital Advisors and take steps to prevent illegal conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: 10:18 p.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Ben Protess

articles.headline: At Comic-Con, Small Tribes Rule
articles.snippet: After nearly a decade in the service of the major film studios and their blockbusters, Comic-Con appears on the verge of a next iteration.
articles.abstract: After nearly a decade in the service of the major film studios and their blockbusters, Comic-Con appears on the verge of a next iteration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — As the pop culture jamboree known as Comic-Con got under way on Thursday, there was an unusual sight outside the 6,500-person hall that in recent years has served as the convention’s movie epicenter.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Program Links Loans to Future Earnings
articles.snippet: Several companies are connecting students and entrepreneurs with private investors willing to lend them money that is later repaid as a percentage of the borrower’s annual salary.
articles.abstract: Several companies are connecting students and entrepreneurs with private investors willing to lend them money that is later repaid as a percentage of the borrower’s annual salary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniel Toole is a 28-year-old architect in Seattle who plans to attend Harvard’s master’s program in urban design. But instead of paying his way with graduate student loans, he is trying to raise money by selling a slice of his future earnings to investors.

articles.headline: Detroit Gap Reveals Industry Dispute on Pension Math
articles.snippet: For several years, the actuarial profession has been fighting over how to calculate the value, in today’s dollars, of future pension payments.
articles.abstract: For several years, the actuarial profession has been fighting over how to calculate the value, in today’s dollars, of future pension payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until mid-June, there was one ray of hope in Detroit’s gathering storm: For all the city’s problems, its pension fund was in pretty good shape. If the city went under, its thousands of retired clerks, police officers, bus drivers and other workers would still be safe.

articles.headline: Under New Chief, a Feistier S.E.C. Emerges
articles.snippet: A flurry of moves appeared to signal that the Securities and Exchange Commission was striking a harder line with Wall Street under its new chairwoman, Mary Jo White.
articles.abstract: A flurry of moves appeared to signal that the Securities and Exchange Commission was striking a harder line with Wall Street under its new chairwoman, Mary Jo White.
articles.lead_paragraph: First the Securities and Exchange Commission rejected a settlement with a high-flying hedge fund manager, Philip A. Falcone. Then it charged another billionaire trader, Steven A. Cohen. By late Friday afternoon, it had accused one of the nation’s largest cities, Miami, of securities fraud.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Frayed Prospects, Despite a Degree
articles.snippet: College graduates from two or three years ago are being overlooked — often deliberately — by recruiters eager to scoop up those from the latest graduating class.
articles.abstract: College graduates from two or three years ago are being overlooked — often deliberately — by recruiters eager to scoop up those from the latest graduating class.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when many job seekers complain that their résumés vanish into a black hole, Charles Wells managed to get a high-level recruiter at Ernst & Young to meet with him in person, twice.

articles.headline: 50 Years of Tough Questions and ‘Thank You, Mr. President’
articles.snippet: Ms. Thomas covered every president from John F. Kennedy to Barack Obama, but her career ended ignominiously over remarks she made about Israeli Jews.
articles.abstract: Ms. Thomas covered every president from John F. Kennedy to Barack Obama, but her career ended ignominiously over remarks she made about Israeli Jews.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Helen Thomas, whose keen curiosity, unquenchable drive and celebrated constancy made her a trailblazing White House correspondent in a press corps dominated by men and who was later regarded as the dean of the White House briefing room, died on Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 92.

articles.headline: A Shuffle of Aluminum, but to Banks, Pure Gold
articles.snippet: Regulators have allowed banks to buy companies that trade in commodities, resulting in huge profits for the banks and higher prices for consumers.
articles.abstract: Regulators have allowed banks to buy companies that trade in commodities, resulting in huge profits for the banks and higher prices for consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich. — Hundreds of millions of times a day, thirsty Americans open a can of soda, beer or juice. And every time they do it, they pay a fraction of a penny more because of a shrewd maneuver by Goldman Sachs and other financial players that ultimately costs consumers billions of dollars.

articles.headline: Despite Education Advances, a Host of Afghan School Woes
articles.snippet: It is widely accepted that demand among Afghans for better schooling — and the actual opportunity to attend, particularly for girls — is at its highest point in decades.
articles.abstract: It is widely accepted that demand among Afghans for better schooling — and the actual opportunity to attend, particularly for girls — is at its highest point in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALANG, Afghanistan — There is not an ounce of fat on the wiry frame of Abdul Wahid, and no wonder.

articles.headline: Math Behind Leak Crackdown: 153 Cases, 4 Years, 0 Indictments
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s aggressive focus on leaks has led to more than twice as many prosecutions as there were in all previous administrations combined.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s aggressive focus on leaks has led to more than twice as many prosecutions as there were in all previous administrations combined.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after President Obama appointed him director of national intelligence in 2009, Dennis C. Blair called for a tally of the number of government officials or employees who had been prosecuted for leaking national security secrets. He was dismayed by what he found.

articles.headline: Some Mormons Search the Web and Find Doubt
articles.snippet: The church is grappling with a wave of disillusionment among members who encountered information that sabotages what they were taught about their faith.
articles.abstract: The church is grappling with a wave of disillusionment among members who encountered information that sabotages what they were taught about their faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the small but cohesive Mormon community where he grew up, Hans Mattsson was a solid believer and a pillar of the church. He followed his father and grandfather into church leadership and finally became an “area authority” overseeing the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints throughout Europe.

articles.headline: Hauling New Treasure Along the Silk Road
articles.snippet: With freight trains as their caravans, manufacturers like Hewlett-Packard are reviving an ancient way to ship products made in China to markets in Western Europe.
articles.abstract: With freight trains as their caravans, manufacturers like Hewlett-Packard are reviving an ancient way to ship products made in China to markets in Western Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: AZAMAT KULYENOV, a 26-year-old train driver, slid the black-knobbed throttle forward, and the 1,800-ton express freight train, nearly a half-mile long, began rolling west across the vast, deserted grasslands of eastern Kazakhstan, leaving the Chinese border behind.

articles.headline: Election Win by Ruling Party Signals Change in Japan
articles.snippet: By securing control of both houses of parliament for up to three years, Sunday’s win offers Prime Minister Shinzo Abe the chance to be the most transformative leader in a decade.
articles.abstract: By securing control of both houses of parliament for up to three years, Sunday’s win offers Prime Minister Shinzo Abe the chance to be the most transformative leader in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese voters handed a landslide victory to the governing Liberal Democrats in parliamentary elections on Sunday, strengthening the grip of a party that promises accelerated changes to Japan’s economy and a shift away from its postwar pacifism.

articles.headline: A Black Box for Car Crashes
articles.snippet: Black boxes in cars can be used to identify safety problems and as evidence in traffic accidents and criminal cases, but also raise privacy concerns.
articles.abstract: Black boxes in cars can be used to identify safety problems and as evidence in traffic accidents and criminal cases, but also raise privacy concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Timothy P. Murray crashed his government-issued Ford Crown Victoria in 2011, he was fortunate, as car accidents go. Mr. Murray, then the lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, was not seriously hurt, and he told the police he was wearing a seat belt and was not speeding.

articles.headline: Case Reveals Cohen’s Links to Dubious Actions at SAC
articles.snippet: In a detailed legal filing, the S.E.C. uses phone records, e-mails and instant messages to paint Steven A. Cohen as a boss deeply engaged in his employees’ questionable behavior at SAC Capital Advisors.
articles.abstract: In a detailed legal filing, the S.E.C. uses phone records, e-mails and instant messages to paint Steven A. Cohen as a boss deeply engaged in his employees’ questionable behavior at SAC Capital Advisors.
articles.lead_paragraph: As government investigators closed in on the billionaire hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen in recent years, his defenders argued that the unusual structure of his firm, SAC Capital Advisors, shielded him from any illegal trading by his employees.

articles.headline: TV Foresees Its Future. Netflix Is There.
articles.snippet: Netflix has given a good shaking to the settled world of television: it has provided its own series, streamed them over the Internet and made them available all at once everywhere.
articles.abstract: Netflix has given a good shaking to the settled world of television: it has provided its own series, streamed them over the Internet and made them available all at once everywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple and Google were back making waves in the television world last week, with reports suggesting they were renewing efforts to use technology to transform the box in your living room.

articles.headline: Files Suggest a Graft Case in China May Expand
articles.snippet: Newly revealed documents suggest that GlaxoSmithKline will not be the only global drug company to come under scrutiny as China widens its investigation.
articles.abstract: Newly revealed documents suggest that GlaxoSmithKline will not be the only global drug company to come under scrutiny as China widens its investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A few weeks ago, when Chinese investigators raided a small travel agency in this fast-growing city, they came upon something startling.

articles.headline: Clones Rule as Hollywood Beats Drum at Comic-Con
articles.snippet: Many of the movies offered to fans in San Diego were sequels or retreads, raising questions on whether “more of the same” was about all Hollywood had.
articles.abstract: Many of the movies offered to fans in San Diego were sequels or retreads, raising questions on whether “more of the same” was about all Hollywood had.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Legendary Entertainment came to Comic-Con last year promoting “Pacific Rim” with all the attending buzz, hype and chatter. Then, a week and a half ago, came the release.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Cries of Betrayal as Detroit Plans to Cut Pensions
articles.snippet: As the city works to spread the burden of bankruptcy, it has proposed cuts that would affect 21,000 pensioners.
articles.abstract: As the city works to spread the burden of bankruptcy, it has proposed cuts that would affect 21,000 pensioners.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Gloria Killebrew, 73, worked for the City of Detroit for 22 years and now spends her days caring for her husband, J. D., who has had three heart attacks and multiple kidney operations, the last of which left him needing dialysis three times a week at the Henry Ford Medical Center in Dearborn, Mich.
articles.byline: By Steven Yaccino and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: For Developing World, a Streamlined Facebook
articles.snippet: To expand its user base, the Internet giant is developing a slimmed-down interface for those whose Internet access is generally via cheap, unsophisticated cellphones.
articles.abstract: To expand its user base, the Internet giant is developing a slimmed-down interface for those whose Internet access is generally via cheap, unsophisticated cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Facebook has been quietly working for more than two years on a project that is vital to expanding its base of 1.1 billion users: getting the social network onto the billions of cheap, simple “feature phones” that have largely disappeared in America and Europe but are still the norm in developing countries like India and Brazil.

articles.headline: In Climbing Income Ladder, Location Matters
articles.snippet: The odds of rising to another income level are notably low in certain cities, like Atlanta and Charlotte, and much higher in New York and Boston.
articles.abstract: The odds of rising to another income level are notably low in certain cities, like Atlanta and Charlotte, and much higher in New York and Boston.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA – Stacey Calvin spends almost as much time commuting to her job — on a bus, two trains and another bus — as she does working part-time at a day care center. She knows exactly where to board the train and which stairwells to use at the stations so that she has the best chance of getting to work on time in the morning and making it home to greet her three children after school.
